A HubSpot Template is a "drag and drop" layout or a coded file that is responsible for the structure of your HubSpot pages.

Template Builder allows you to create "drag and drop" layouts with various HubSpot module types or to code your own HTML template from scratch. Once you finish a template, content is added via the Page or Post Editor, and a HubSpot CSS file is applied to give your final webpage to give it the correct look and feel.

To create a new Template:

  • Navigate to Content > Design Manager.
  • Select Templates > click New template.
  • Choose the Template Builder or click here to learn how to create an HTML Template.
  • Choose the type of Template that you would like to create.
  • Give your new Template a name, and select a folder to save the Template in.
  • When ready, click Save to finish.

If you are using a Layout Builder, you are able to add new modules, swap module types, add default content, group modules, add custom classes, link HubSpot CSS files, rearrange modules by dragging them, and much more.
Once your template is setup, clicking the Publish Changes button compiles your layout into a template that your pages will use for their structure. By spending time fully setting up a Template's structure, from the beginning, you can save time creating content in the form of Pages and Posts.

For further insight, please follow the resource linked below.

  • How to structure your content using Template Builder
  • How to Code HTML Page and Email Templates

Only Enterprise accounts have the ability to select an alternative domain on individual pages, and thus publish pages in the same tool (landing pages, site pages, or blog) across multiple subdomains. Follow the instructions below to select an alternative domain for one of your pages:

  • Navigate to Content > Content Settings
  • Click Domain Manager on the left-hand side of the page
  • Select Connect another domain and add your desired subdomain
  • Copy the CNAME provided for your subdomain(s) from the Email and Landing Page Domain Manager page, and point your subdomain(s) to the CNAME in your domain name server settings (this is outside of HubSpot, either with the registrar you purchased your URL from or your name server host)
  • Additional subdomains will be left as Secondary to the Primary subdomain
  • Secondary domains can be selected for a specific Landing Page to override the primary. You can override the primary when editing a Landing Page under the Settings > Page URL section.

Related articles:

  • Can I host my HubSpot content on multiple subdomains?

Please follow the directions noted below to publish your COS sitemap to Google Webmaster's Tools.

  • First, please be aware that to view the sitemap for your HubSpot hosted content, you simple have to append /sitemap.xml to the end of your domain name. For example, http://www.yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml.
    • Click here if you would like to know how you can modify your COS sitemap.
  • Log into your Google account and go to your Google Webmaster Tools.
  • Click on the red Add a Site button. (You may need to verify the site in order to submit a sitemap for it.)
  • Next, click on your site URL > click Crawl in the left-side menu > click Sitemaps
  • Click on the red Add/Test a Sitemap button
  • Fill in the URL of your sitemap XML file (example: http://www.yourdomain.com/sitemap.xml) > click Submit

As part of the newer Website Add-On package, HubSpot does provide the option to host secure content via SSL. Please follow the link below, and submit on the form - Doing so will alert our Team of your interest in this option, at which point our Team will reach out to you with further details. 

http://www.hubspot.com/request-ssl

For more information about HubSpot's SSL offerings, please contact your Customer Success Manager.

While HubSpot does offer some SSL solutions, it remains against the HubSpot Terms of Service to capture or store sensitive information in the HubSpot contacts database. This includes confidential data such as personal credit card information, account numbers, passwords, etc., which is information that is considered Personally Identifiable Information.

Your ability to host HubSpot content on multiple subdomains depends on your subscription level.

Basic accounts can host all content types on a single subdomain.

Professional accounts can use a single subdomain per content type (e.g. info.yousite.com could be primary for Landing Pages, blog.yoursite.com could be primary for Blog, etc.).

Enterprise accounts can set a primary subdomain for each content type and can additionally publish to any connected domain (multi-domain publishing). To publish content to a different subdomain, use the Alternative Domain dropdown from the Settings tab of the content editor.

You can connect additional subdomains to HubSpot, but note that these subdomains will be considered secondary and will redirect to your primary domain. 

To change which domain is the primary (or default) domain for a particular content tool type, follow the steps below:

  • Navigate to Content > Content Settings.
  • Choose Domain Manager from the left sidebar menu.
  • Click Edit to the right of the domain you would like to make primary. If you have not already connected the subdomain to HubSpot, please follow the steps here.
  • Select the radio box for Content Optimization System Tool(s) and then the checkboxes for the content tool(s) you would like to host on that subdomain by default (remember that Basic accounts will only be able to select one primary subdomain for all of the COS Tools).
  • Click the Save Changes button.

Via HubSpot's Social Publishing tool, you can post messages to social media channels you have connected to your HubSpot portal. However, there are times when such posting proves unsuccessful. Please find below the most common errors and further details you can use as you attempt to resolve such errors. 

  • Image rejected - Please ensure that your image is below the size limit and within the size parameters recommended for the social network you're trying to post to. Also, be sure to check that the picture's file format is JPEG or PNG and that the URL where the image is being hosted is still live. When attaching an image to your social message, we strongly recommend using an image that is featured in the page you're sharing.
  • Authorization failed - Make sure that your account still has posting authorized for the HubSpot App. An easy way to ensure that your social account is currently authorized is to re-authorize it from the Social Settings page (don't delete it, just connect the account again). 
  • 3rd Party Network issue - Even APIs sometimes have bad days, once you've checked that your image and account are working, go ahead and clone your social message and try posting it again.

Each time an email address is entered into the email field on a HubSpot form, the address is immediately validated by HubSpot. This functionality is built into all HubSpot forms and does not need to be enabled. If the email address is not valid (does not exist, is misspelled, etc.), the user will not be able to submit on the form.

There are also a few methods to provide additional protection against spam form submissions:

Block free email providers or specific domains

You may want to add additional validation to the email field on your form: 

  • Navigate to Contacts > Forms.
  • Click on the name of the form you need additional validation for to edit it. Then click pencil icon to the right of the Email field.
  • Now you will see a couple of options for adding further validation to your email field:
    1. Email Domains to Block - this is useful if you have received spam submissions from a particular domain in the past (or if an email domain that you want to block is not covered by the second option below)
    2. Block free email providers - you should use this if you only want submissions from domains associated with businesses, etc. Click the See list link next to this option to find out which free providers will be blocked.
  • Click Done Editing when you are satisfied with your changes.

Add a hidden field to your form

You can add a hidden field to your form to determine which, if any, submissions are spam. After adding the field, you can create a list of contacts who submitted a value for that hidden field. Real, human visitors won't be able to submit on a hidden field on a form, but spam bots will submit information on all fields, including the hidden one. 

  • Navigate to Contacts > Forms.
  • Select the form you'd like to edit and add the field you'd like to make hidden.
  • Click the pencil icon to the right of the field.
  • Check the box next to Make field hidden.
  • Click Done Editing > Save Form.

Enable CAPTCHA

CAPTCHA gives you an added layer of protection against spam submission. It adds a step to your form, requiring visitors to verify that they are not a robot before submitting. To learn more about CAPTCHA and how to enable it on your forms, check out this article. 

 

Please note: If you are using the Forms API, you must write your own custom validation. The built-in validation used for HubSpot forms does not apply when POSTing directly to the API.

Related articles:

  • How can I prevent people from submitting a form using certain email domains?
  • Why is my form telling me to enter a valid email address?

To add a new module within a Flexible Column in the content editor:

  • Click on the plus sign icon on the left-side of the screen
  • Upon clicking the plus sign, a menu of modules will appear for you to choose from.
  • Click and drag the desired module type into the content area and drop the module where you would like it to appear on the page. You may drag and drop the module into one of the highlighted areas only.
  • When you are done adding the new module(s), click the X in the menu of modules on the left side of the screen to minimize that window
  • Be sure to Save or Update your changes at the top of the page

Only pages using templates containing flexible columns will see the plus sign icon to click on. You may only drag and drop new modules into areas on the page that utilize flexible columns. If you notice you are not able to drop the module in a particular area, it is because that area may not be a flexible column.

  • How to add flexible columns to your template
  • How to reorder modules in a flexible column from the content editor's UI

When a HubSpot portal is integrated with Salesforce, the HubSpot Owner contact property is populated with a Salesforce's Lead/Contact Owner value. However, in some instances, when reviewing the HubSpot Owner contact property in HubSpot, you may not see all of your Salesforce owners. This is because the missing owners have not had a Salesforce lead/contact synced to HubSpot.

The solution in this case is to simply wait until a Salesforce lead/contact, whose owned by a missing owner, syncs over to HubSpot, because this will make that missing owner value show up in the HubSpot Owner contact property. As an alternative, you can add the Salesforcer owner in question as an actual user in your HubSpot portal (with the same email address used in his/her Salesforce profile) - Doing so will add him/her under the HubSpot Owner contact property.

Related Articles:

  • Where do the owners in the HubSpot Owners contact property come from?

This particular error basically means that we're unable to sync a HubSpot contact because the corresponding lead or contact has been deleted in Salesforce. The error is harmless in that it does not prevent any data from syncing, but is a good indication that HubSpot and Salesforce might become out of sync over time.

To fix this, navigate to the contact in HubSpot that is not syncing to Salesforce. Scroll until you see the Salesforce Sync section on the left-hand side of the contact record, then click the Undelete button.

If you would like to prevent this from happening in the future, please follow the directions noted below.

  • Navigate to your Account Menu > Integrations.
  • Under the Salesforce Integration, click on Settings.
  • Scroll down to Delete in HubSpot when deleted in Salesforce and select the appropriate check-boxes. When ready click on Save.
  • How do I fix an error displayed on the Salesforce Sync Error screen?
  • How to adjust your Salesforce integration settings

Please follow the steps detailed below to map a Salesforce formula field to a HubSpot contact or company property.

  • Navigate to your Account Menu > Integrations.
  • Under Salesforce, click on Settings > Contacts Field Mappings > Add new field mapping.
  • On the Create Mapping window, proceed to:
    1. Select the desired HubSpot contact property under What HubSpot property would you like to map?
    2. Select the desired Salesforce formula field under What Salesforce field would you like to map it to?
    3. Select the appropriate mapping update rule under When should HubSpot data update the corresponding Salesforce field? (Note: "Always" and "Only if Blank in Salesforce" will not be options for formula fields.)
  • When ready, click on Save Mapping to create the mapping.

Great, you can now set mappings between Salesforce formula fields and HubSpot contact properties.

Please note: After you have set up your field mapping to a Salesforce formula field, it's important to note that an update to the formula field on its own won't automatically trigger a sync. A non-formula field must be updated to trigger a sync, at which point the updated value in the formula field will sync over.

 

Related articles:

  • Why is my custom Salesforce field not syncing to HubSpot?

  • Does HubSpot Sync with the Salesforce Opportunity Object?

If tracking URL visits are not showing up in the Sources Report as expected, verify the following:

  • Visits will only appear in the Sources Report if the tracking URL has been clicked at least once during the time frame of the current view. Click on the dropdown at the top of the Sources Report to change the time frame.
  • Make sure that the HubSpot Tracking Code is installed on the page that the tracking URL is linking to. Tracking URLs will not record visits for pages without the tracking code, such as pages external from your website, PDFs, images, and documents.
  • Check that the tracking URL was created with the right parameters and correctly formatted URL, learn more about creating tracking URLs.
  • If testing visits to this tracking URL, make sure that you are not visiting your website from a filtered IP address. The current IPs being blocked from analytics are located under Reports > Reports Settings.

If a tracking URL is showing visits in the Sources Report, but not under the expected bucket, learn more about how HubSpot categorizes visits based on tracking parameters.

In the case you're using HubSpot tracking URLs in Google AdWords ads, please be sure to use the Full Tracking URL, and not the Shortened Tracking URL. Due to recent changes in AdWords ads, users will now need to use Upgraded URLs. Also, it is imperative that you insert your HubSpot Full Tracking URL into the Final destination field in AdWords ads, not the Destination field. In addition to this, the Final destination field will need to contain the same domain as the landing page URL. For example, if your ad's landing page is http://offers.yoursite.com/demo your Final destination field will need to contain yoursite.com.

After a visit is categorized as a Paid Search visit, HubSpot looks at the referring site, in particular the value passed in the "q" parameter to determine what was the search term the contact used to find your site. Let's go a bit more in depth:

  • Navigate to Reports > Sources.
  • Look below the bar graph, but in particular review the Paid Search information - Click on number under the Contacts column; doing so will prompt you to a page listing contacts bucketed under the Paid Search source.
  • Select any contact, and once you are on the contact's profile, click on the Properties link located on the left hand-side.
  • Search for the contact property named First Referring Site - This contact property contains the contact's referring site.
  • As detailed below, within the parameters of the referring site, the "q=" parameter details the search term the contact used to find your site.
  • However, please be aware that there are instances when the referring site does not provide such information.
  • If the "q=" parameter isn't present in the first referring site, HubSpot will next look for the "utm_term" value in the URL to determine the keyword used. If this is not present, you will see the visit sub-categorized as Content network (Adsense or other).

There are two ways to track Google Adwords campaigns using the Sources Report in HubSpot:

If you are using the Hubspot Ads Add-on, you will get the gclid tracking from Auto-tagging automatically, as well as the ability to tag your HubSpot campaigns through the tool, so you don't need to make any of these changes or worry about tracking URLs.

To see all visits for your ads under a single campaign:

  1. Enable Auto-Tagging for Google Adwords.
  2. This will categorize all of these visits in the Sources Report under Paid Search > Auto-Tagged PPC.
  3. All visits will be bucketed together under Auto-Tagged PPC because HubSpot is unable to detect campaign names from Google's auto-tagged URLs (ex. auto-tagged URL = www.company.com/?gclid=123xyz).

Please note: if no search term is provided, you will see the visit sub-categorized as Content network (Adsense or other).

 

To see visits for each ad separated by a campaign name:

  1. Disable Auto-Tagging for Google Adwords and create Tracking URLs in HubSpot to use for your ad's destination URL. This will allow visits from Adwords to be bucketed under separate campaigns, based on the campaign name set within the tracking URLs. Note: If auto-tagging is enabled when tracking URLs are used, visits will appear as expected in the HubSpot Sources Report, but Google Analytics may display multiple entries within their reports for different data types.
  2. Create a Tracking URL in HubSpot to use as the destination URL for your Adwords Campaign. This will bucket the visits under Paid Search and display the campaign name within the Sources Report.
  3. Navigate to Reports > Reports Home > Tracking URL Builder. Use the following criteria for the tracking URL:
  • URL = URL of your page
  • Campaign = choose an existing campaign name or create a new campaign name for your ad.
  • Source = Paid Search

Within the Sources Report breakdown for Paid Search, HubSpot will drilldown into the campaign name and search term. Source will not display in the graph.

If you are also reporting on your Adwords campaigns in Google Analytics, the source may display in your reports. Learn more about the traffic source dimensions used in Google Analytics. If you customize the source and medium parameters for Google Analytics, HubSpot will categorize a visit as Paid Search as long as at least one of the parameters (source or medium) contains "ppc" or "cpc" or "adwords."

Please note: if no search term is provided, you will see the visit sub-categorized as Content network (Adsense or other).

The HubSpot for Wordpress plugin has been deprecated and replaced by the HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress plugin. HubSpot no longer develops nor supports the features of the HubSpot for Wordpress plugin. 

Adding wp_footer to your theme

In order for the HubSpot plugin to add HubSpot's tracking code to your site, you must include the wp_footer function in your WordPress theme‰Ûªs footer. Most WordPress themes include this by default, but if your theme does not, you will need to include the following PHP tag in your theme‰Ûªs footer file (usually named footer.php):

If you are a Wordpress admin, you can edit the footer by navigating to Appearance > Editor. For more information on the footer.php function, check out WordPress's documentation here.

After ensuring that your theme's footer includes <?php wp_footer(); ?>, follow these steps to check that the tracking code is firing.

As of August 24th 2015, HubSpot will no longer develop or support the "HubSpot for Wordpress" plugin. HubSpot has released a simplified version of the plugin, "HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress". The deprecated "HubSpot for Wordpress" plugin will continue to function, but will not be maintained nor supported by HubSpot. The following article outlines how to switch from the old plugin to the new official HubSpot plugin.

Check to see if your site is using HubSpot shortcodes

The HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress plugin does not include a built in shortcode feature for embedding forms and CTAs. Forms and CTAs can be embedded directly in your pages and posts. Deactivating the HubSpot for Wordpress plugin without swapping the shortcodes for embeds will cause any shortcode generated forms and CTAs not to render.

Before you switch to the new official plugin, make sure that your site is not using HubSpot form shortcodes:

  • On the Wordpress sidebar, navigate to HubSpot > Shortcodes
  • Check to see if you have form embeds saved in fields next to shortcodes
  • If so, locate where the pages on your site where the shortcodes are in use
  • Remove the shortcode (ex: [hs_form id="0"]) and paste the form embed code directly into the Text view of the editor
  • Update your page or post

Next ensure that you are not using CTA shortcodes:

  • On the Wordpress sidebar, navigate to Calls to Action
  • Check to see if you have CTAs saved in Wordpress
  • If so, where the pages on your site where the shortcodes are in use
  • Remove the shortcode (ex: [hs_action id="0"]) and paste the CTA embed code directly into the Text view of the editor
  • Update your page or post

Deactivate HubSpot for Wordpress

Before installing the HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress plugin, you must deactivate the HubSpot plugin for Wordpress. It is recommended to leave the plugin installed and deactive, rather than uninstalling. To deactivate the plugin:

  • On the Wordpress sidebar, click Plugins > Installed Plugins
  • Under HubSpot for Wordpress, click Deactivate

Install HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress

Now you are ready to install and activate the HubSpot Tracking code for Wordpress.

  • On the Wordpress sidebar, navigate to Plugins > Add New
  • Search for "HubSpot Tracking Code for Wordpress"
  • Click Install Now
  • Click Activate Plugin

Enter your HubID

Finally, you need to enter your HubID to start tracking view data in HubSpot

  • On the Wordpress sidebar, navigate to Settings > HubSpot Settings
  • Enter your HubID
  • Press Save Settings

You can now add this property to your forms or set the value with a workflow.

After sending an email from HubSpot, you may see the post-send stats and notice which contacts were and were not delivered the email. Even for those contacts showing as having been delivered the email, some of your contacts might not actually see the email appear in their inbox as expected.

This can be confusing because a contact expecting to receive an email from you may reach out and claim they never received the email, so you check the post-send stats and see they were marked as delivered...now what?

There are two common possible explanations: the email is sitting in a SPAM/Junk folder in their inbox or it is in a quarantine area. In both cases, the email was received by their email server which is why HubSpot will mark them categorically as delivered.

Be sure to check out this article called What steps can my contacts take to ensure they receive our marketing emails?

The email ended up in their SPAM/Junk folder in their inbox

The email was successfully delivered to the contact's inbox, but may have ended up in their SPAM/Junk folder. Ask the contact to check that area of their inbox to see if the email is there. HubSpot will still mark the contact as delivered even when the email ends up in the contact's SPAM/Junk folder.

To prevent this, ask the contact to add your email's 'From' address to their address book. Also, be sure you have an email sending domain setup in HubSpot and that email sending domain is used in the'From'  address in the emails you send from HubSpot.

The email ended up in a quarantine area on their email server

HubSpot marks contacts as having been delivered an email based on a delivery notification received in the background from the contact's email server; like a delivery notification. Once this delivery notification is received, HubSpot will mark the contact as delivered.

The contact may have a SPAM protection software installed and the email was caught up in quarantine holding it hostage. Categorically the email was indeed accepted by their email server, but it was seen as suspicious and not allowed to deliver into their personal inbox. If this happens, ask the contact to consult with their IT/Email person to check their email server. Provide your contact the subject line of the email, the from address and the time/date the email was showing as delivered. This information will help their IT/Email person investigate the whereabouts of the said delivered email.

To prevent this, ask the contact to add your email's 'From' address to their address book. Also, be sure you have an email sending domain setup in HubSpot and that email sending domain is used in the'From'  address in the emails you send from HubSpot.

  • Navigate to Content > Email > click Sent.
  • Select the sent email in question > click on Show more info - Doing so will reveal the From address.

Related articles:

What steps can my contacts take to ensure they receive our marketing emails?
What can I do to make my emails look less like spam?
Why did my email show up in my SPAM folder?

We understand it‰Ûªs important for marketers to know if recipients are opening their emails on a Desktop or Mobile devices. Since we do not know the device type for emails opened in Gmail, we estimate the device breakdown based on the Desktop to Mobile ratio of your email on other email clients.

Example: In the case below 40% of opens are Desktop and 20% are Mobile giving a Desktop to Mobile ratio of 2:1.

We will use this ratio to estimate the device split for the 40% opens on Gmail (e.g. 40% / 2:1 = 26.7% : 13.3%). We then add these Gmail estimates to your Desktop and Mobile opens as detailed below:

  • Desktop: 66.7% (40% + Gmail Estimate 26.7%)
  • Mobile: 33.3% (20% + Gmail Estimate 13.3%)

Making your overall Opens by Device Type look like this:

You may re-send an email to more contacts after the email was originally sent. This includes sending to additional lists of contacts as well as individual contacts.

Please note: this feature is only available for Batch email sends, not for Automated, A/B Test, or Follow-Up emails. This feature is also not available for Batch emails using Smart Send.

Additionally, If you choose to re-send the email to the same recipient list the original email was sent to, HubSpot will only re-send the email to contacts who were added to the recipient list after the original send. In other words, the re-send will not go to any contacts who received the first send. 

To re-send an email to additional contacts who were not on the original send, please follow the steps below:

  • Navigate to Content > Email.
  • Select the Sent folder in the left pane, and click on the name of the email you wish to re-send. After having accessed the email, click Send to more in the top-right corner.
  • Next, you will be able to select individuals and/or lists to re-send the email to. Select the list(s) and/or individual(s) you want to send to by clicking on Add recipients. You may also use the Exclude recipients button to select a list of contacts you wish to exclude from receiving the new email at hand.

    You do not need to exclude the contacts you already sent the email to, as no contact can receive the same email twice. That also means that if a contact is on the original email send list, and is also on the additional list you are re-sending to, they will not receive the email a second time.
  • When you're ready to send the email message, simply click on Send.
  • If you wish to re-send an email to the same contacts, you will need to clone the email. Learn how to clone an email.

• Emails will not be sent to contacts marked as Opted-out of email communication in their profile from our Marketing platform.
  • Contacts can choose to resubscribe to all or specific email types.
  • Opt-out status is tied to a contact's email address, not the record. If a contact's email address is changed, their previous opt-out status will not apply unless they choose to opt-out again using the new address. 
  • Please note that you can still send emails from the HubSpot CRM to contacts whom have opted out of emails sent from your Marketing platform, as CRM emails are 1:1 and not sent to a group of contacts at once. Also, If you are sending a transactional email, this email type overrides opt-out status and the email will be sent.

Related Articles :

  • How can I resubscribe a customer?
  • Where can I set email types?

This article reviews possible causes for issues when importing lists.

  • Your import file must be saved as a CSV file to be compatible with the HubSpot Import tool.
  • Your CSV must include email addresses for each contact you are importing.
  • You cannot import values for IP Address or Create Date.
  • All columns in the CSV file must have headers to indicate which contact property the column refers to.
  • If any of the columns you're importing do not correspond with a property or property value in HubSpot, you need to create a property to store the information in that column.
  • All responses to questions on the Confirm list validity screen must be True for the import to proceed.
  • Confirm that your CSV file is UTF-8 encoded. To ensure that your CSV file is UTF-8 encoded you can follow the methods listed below.

    Please be aware that there may be times UTF-Encoding in Excel does not work as expected, therefore the second method is preferable.

    • Method 1
      • To check this in Excel, open the csv and click File > Save As.
      • Enter your preferred filename.
      • Click the drop-down beside Save as File Type and make sure CSV (comma-delimited) is selected.
      • Click the Tools button at the bottom of the window and choose Web Options.
      • Go to the Encoding tab.
      • Under "Save this document as," click the drop-down menu and choose Unicode (UTF-8).
    • Method 2: You can also create an UTF-8 based .csv file using Excel and Notepad.
      • Open the Excel file > navigate to Menu > Save As > Name the file and select Unicode Text (*.txt) as the type to Save as > Click Save.
      • Open the file in Notepad. You will have to replace all tab characters with commas.
      • Go to File > Save As > name the file > change Encoding to UTF-8 > on the file name, change the extension from .txt to .csv > Save.
      • Review the icon on the file, as it should now be a MS Excel icon.
      • Open the newer .csv file in Excel and review the data only. Do not save the file in Excel as it will present an enconding issue once more. If any of the data is erroneous, follow the steps just detailed again.
  • You can also try to encode the file via Google docs.

If any of the above possibilities do not answer your question, please contact HubSpot Support by clicking on the Help button in the bottom, right-hand corner of your HubSpot portal.

Related articles:
  • How do I import contacts?
  • Why is my list taking a long time to import?
  • What does it mean when my import error says "Header and row sizes don't match"?
  • Why does my CSV import give me an email doesn't validate error?
  • Why am I getting the warning "Cannot Parse Property" when importing a list?
  • Why does my imported list have fewer contacts than my original spreadsheet?

When importing values to a Date Picker property using the basic (default) import, the date values must be formatted as MM/DD/YYYY to be passed properly into HubSpot. For example, 10/08/2014 represents October 8, 2014.

However, you can use the advanced view in the import process to choose a format for date properties that you have on your import (Note: all date properties in a single CSV file must be in the same format).

  • After you have selected your CSV for import, toggle the advanced view
  • In the "Please choose a default format for date properties" section, choose the desired date format for this particular import.
  • Using the October 8, 2014 example above, your options are:
    • MM/DD/YYYY (10/08/2014)
    • DD/MM/YYYY (08/10/2014)
    • YYYY-MM-DD (2014-10-08)

Note: At this time, it is not possible to import time stamps into a Date Picker property.

Related articles:

  • How do I import contacts?
  • Why am I getting the error "Cannot Parse Property" when importing a list?
  • Why is my contact import failing or returning and error?

Follow these steps to go live on the HubSpot COS with a Bluehost registered domain that has its nameserver set to Blue Host. If you moved your nameserver to another host after registering the domain with Blue Host, you'd instead need to make the changes on the other host.

In order to properly go live on the HubSpot COS, you need to set up a 301 redirect/domain forwarding from the root domain (domain.com) to the subdomain you are connecting to HubSpot (subdomain.domain.com) in Bluehost. In the instructions below that address setting up that redirect in Bluehost, you may find that you need to either set up the redirect yourself by editing the .htaaccess file, which takes a good amount of technical know-how, or contact Bluehost support to have them set up that 301 redirect for you. HubSpot Support does not support the editing or updating of your .htaaccess file, so you will need to contact Bluehost if you cannot do it yourself. If your DNS provider does not provide a 301 redirect, please reach out to our Support team and they can help you with a solution. 

In HubSpot:

  • Navigate to Content > Content Settings.
  • Click on the Domain Manager link in the Content Optimization System Tools side menu. 
  • Click Connect Another HubSpot COS Domain button at the bottom of the HubSpot COS Domains table.
  • Add your new domain to connect and configure how it will connect to your HubSpot content. If this is the first domain you'll be connecting to your HubSpot account, you'll probably want to make it the primary domain for all tools. To do that, just click on the button next to the make primary for the following tool(s) option and then check the box next to Blog Posts, Email, Landing Pages, and Site Pages.
  • You will want to connect www.mydomain.com and not mydomain.com because HubSpot's COS is able to load pages and files at high-speed and protect your site against malicious attacks (like DDOS) attacks, but the technology that enables this will only work with what are known as CNAME records. Root domains, a domain without WWW, cannot connect with CNAME records, but WWW domains can. So you will need to connect the WWW version of your domain to HubSpot in order for this to work. The non WWW version will be redirected to the WWW version, so that visitors will always be able to get to your website.
  • Click Connect Domain.
  • Copy down the CNAME record provided, ex: 123456.webhost77.hubspot.net

In Blue Host:

  • Navigate to bluehost.com.
  • Click login in the top right. 
  • Locate and click on cpanel in the upper left hand corner of the navigation menu.
  • Scroll down to the Domain management Section and click on DNS Zone Editor.
  • If you have multiple domains, select the correct domain in the Select a Domain section and click Reload.
  • Take a screenshot of the DNS record set-up within the account for your records.
  • Locate and delete the WWW if it's in the A-Host section.
  • Either add in the WWW CNAME record or edit the WWW CNAME record by pointing it to HubSpot's CNAME record.
  • Save changes.
  • At the top of the page click on redirect.
  • Select Permanent 301
  • To redirect to the WWW.yoursite.com
  • Select the Do Not Redirect WWW option.
  • Select Make this a wildcard redirect to redirect traffic from yoursite.com/{rest-of-url} to www.yoursite.com/{rest-of-url} (without this, all URLs on your root domain, yoursite.com/{rest-of-url} will redirect to www.yoursite.com)
  • Add this redirect.

If you find that need further assistance setting up that wildcard redirect in Bluehost, you'll need to either set up the redirect yourself by editing the .htaaccess file, which takes a good amount of technical know-how, or contact Bluehost support to have them set up that 301 redirect for you. HubSpot Support does not support the editing or updating of your .htaaccess file

  • It may take anywhere from a couple hours to 24-48 hours for these DNS changes to propagate, at which point you'll see the domain is properly connected in the HubSpot Domain Manager.

In HubSpot, you can add an email sending domain for DKIM (Domain Keys Identified Mail) email authentication, which is used to verify a sender's identity. Part of this process involves your Domain Host validating the email domain. You can verify that the TXT (Text) record has been connected successfully using a public query tool. 

Please note: you do not need to set up an Email Sending Domain in your HubSpot account if you are using a HubSpot Dedicated IP for email. This feature is only used for HubSpot accounts using a Shared IP.

To verify your email sending domain, follow the steps below:

  • Navigate to http://www.digwebinterface.com/.
  • In the Hostnames or IP addresses box, we'll check the SMTPAPI email sending domain for hubspot.com. So we'll enter "smtpapi._domainkey.hubspot.com" (So, if your website is "mywebsite.com" you can check your email sending domain by typing in "smtpapi._domainkey.mywebsite.com".)
  • Click the dropdown menu under Type > choose TXT. 
  • Click Dig to look at the TXT record for your email sending domain.
  • The bottom will show the value of the "smtpapi._domainkey.hubspot.com" TXT record. This will contain a long string of characters that mirror the TXT record value provided to you from HubSpot (as seen here.) 

Related article:

  • How do I setup my Email Sending Domains?

As detailed below, when using the Page Performance tool to optimize your page, you may encounter instances when the tool indicates that it is not detecting a CTA (Call-to-Action) on the page you are reviewing.

This particular warning is caused by either of the reasons noted below:

  • What seems like a CTA is actually just an image that is linked to another page. Remember that a CTA is a button, not an image.
  • In cases where you embed a HubSpot CTA on an external, non-HubSpot page, the CTA's embed code may be broken. Please be aware that in order for our Page Performance tool to detect a HubSpot CTA on one of your external pages, the entire CTA's embed code needs to be embedded, down to the last character. Furthermore, if your HubSpot tracking code is not embedded on your external pages, Page Performance will not be able to detect the CTA (please make sure the tracking code is also embedded appropriately with no extraneous characters).

Please note: the Page Performance tool is not able to detect non-HubSpot CTAs on your pages (HubSpot or external pages alike).

If either of these scenarios does not fit your particular situation, please reach out to our Support Team for further assistance.

Related articles:

  • How to create a Call-to-Action (CTA)
  • How to analyze your website page performance
  • How to analyze your landing page performance

Our Marketing Grader provides you a holistic measure of your website's likeliness to succeed at inbound marketing, and indications on what you should do to improve this likeliness, otherwise known as your marketing grade. The higher your grade is, the better. Marketing Grader bases its grades on five factors:

  • Blogging
    • Ensure you have a blog set up.
    • Also, make sure an RSS feed is set up.
    • A link to your blog from your home page is in place.
    • Social sharing buttons to your blog are also set.
    • Social subscription options to your blog are added.
    • Email subscription options to your blog are enabled.
  • Social Media
    • You have set up a Twitter account.
    • Also ensure a Facebook business page is set.
    • Links to your social media accounts are set from within your home page.
  • SEO
    • Add alt tags to your images.
    • Minimize the use of page titles with your company name.
    • Use unique page descriptions.
  • Lead Generation
    • Create landing pages with forms to generate leads.
    • Set up marketing automation.
    • Set up analytics to measure your marketing efforts.
  • Mobile
    • Use @media queries or a mobile stylesheet.
    • Add a meta viewport tag.

To review more details on these various factors:

  • Navigate to Reports > Competitors.
  • Locate the Marketing Grade next to your domain, and click on it.
  • Simply select the desired factor on the left hand side of the page > click on the Show link next to Checklist > Show details next to the subsequent sub-factors.

Related Articles:

  • Why does Marketing Grader show an error when trying to grade my website?
  • How do I update the Marketing Grader report?

If some properties are not displaying on your form when you add it to a landing page, it is likely that you have smart fields activated on your form and HubSpot remembers you from previous interactions or testing. Smart fields are hidden if the visitor has previously answered this question or if the contact already has a value for this property.

Check if you have smart fields enabled by following the steps below:

  • Navigate to Contacts > Forms
  • Click on the name of the form you're working on to open it
  • If the icon on the far-right of a field is blue, that indicates that the field is smart
  • If youwant the field to be displayed any time someone views your form, regardless of whether or not you already have that information in your Contacts database for that visitor, turn off the smart functionality on the field
  • Click Preview and toggle the checkboxes in the left sidebar to preview form behavior

If the field you cannot see is not a smart field, it may be in the Queued questions section. Queued questions replace smart fields on the form when the value for the smart field is known. For that reason, fields designated as queued questions may not show up every time you view the form.

As a side note, you can test out the form, and view the page as if you were a visitor that has not filled out the form previously by simply clearing your browser's cache and cookies before visiting the page. You can also view the page as a visitor if you have Google Chrome via its Incognito function.

Related articles:

  • What is a smart field?
  • How do I make a field on my form a smart field?
  • Do I have smart fields?
  • How to create a form for your landing page

If your externally embedded form is not working or is not collecting data, follow the steps below to verify the form embed code.

  • Bring up your form embed code in HubSpot (see this article for instructions on how to do that.)
  • Navigate to the page on Wordpress where your Hubspot form is (use a new window and place it next to the window with your form embed code open so you can see both at once)
  • Right-click anywhere on the page > choose View page source
  • Locate the form embed code on the page by hitting Ctrl+F (or Cmd+F on a Mac) on your keyword and searching for your HubSpot ID (please note: the HubSpot analytics tracking code also contains your HubSpot ID, so look for formID as well to avoid confusion)
  • Compare the embed code on the page to the embed code in the form editor; the snippets should match
  • WordPress may convert "&&" in the embedded form code to "&&" which will break the functionality of the code
  • XHTML Wordpress themes will add <![CDATA[ ]]> tags around the Javascript, which should not affect whether the form renders.

If re-embedding the form does not resolve the issue, you may need to use a third-party plugin to add the form to the page/post in the form of a shortcode. One plugin that allows users to insert CTA codes via a shortcode (therefore preserving the script tags) is Insert HTML Snippet which can be downloaded here: https://wordpress.org/plugins/insert-html-snippet/. Wrapping your form embed code in <div> tags may also prevent Wordpress from adjusting the code.

If your embedded form does not redirect to the correct page when it is submitted, you may need to edit the redirect URL in the Forms tool. Before you copy the form embed code to add it to your site, you need to designate a URL for where the form should redirect after it is submitted.

Follow the steps in this article to find your form embed code and set a redirect URL.

Related articles:

  • Can I use a HubSpot form on my external site?
  • How do I style my embedded form?
  • Can I have an inline thank-you message for my externally embedded form?

These numbers are pulled from Analytics.

  • If a submission was just made, you must first wait for analytics to process in order for this to be reflected here.
  • Ensure the correct date range is set in the top left corner of the screen, by default the range is set to Last 30 Days.
Additional troubleshooting steps:
  • Submissions from filtered IP addresses will not show up here
  • Ensure the tracking code is installed and the submissions are not being made through the Forms API

If your form has multiple columns, you no longer make individual fields smart, instead you make entire rows smart.

  • Smart fields are hidden when we already know the visitors information.
  • Therefore, the form would look very different to each visitor if just individual fields were smart rather than entire rows.
  • For example:
    • A form has three fields in a row, First Name, Last Name, and Email.
    • If the Last Name field is smart and the visitor already has a value for Last Name, this field would be hidden and Email would shift over to the left.
    • This would result in an empty space in the row.
  • Instead, you must now make an entire row smart, therefore the integrity of the form is maintained and the row is only hidden if we know all the values for each field.

HubSpot forms create new contacts when they collect a visitor‰Ûªs email address via the default HubSpot Email property. The default property that you should be using to collect email addresses on is called "Email" and is not editable (because it is a default property).

If your HubSpot forms are using a custom email field as opposed to the default property above, HubSpot will not record the submission as a contact. Replace your custom property with Email to ensure that all submissions are properly recorded. Follow the steps below to do so:

  • Navigate to Contacts > Forms
  • Click on the name of the form you're working on
  • Open the Fields tab on the left-hand side of the page > locate the Email property and drag it onto the form
  • If you have a custom email property already on the form, hover over the custom property > click the trash can icon that comes up to remove it from the form

Going forward, remember to use the default Email property in all of your forms.

Related articles:

  • How to use contact properties
  • How do I export form submissions?

Progressive profiling replaces questions you have already asked a visitor with new questions in the order you decide. This increases conversion rates by keeping forms short, but also allows you to learn more about your visitors over time (as they return to your website and answer different questions every time). Please note: progressive profiling is only available to Professional and Enterprise subscriptions.

  • Navigate to Contacts > Form
  • Click on the name of the form that you want to edit
  • Make a field "smart" by clicking on the icon with two squares and two arrows
  • Add fields to the Queued questions section of the form editor to replace smart fields once they have a known value

Once you save your form, the properties in the queued questions section will now replace known smart fields on your live form. So, for example, if your contact has already told you their company's name, the form will now ask for their annual revenue (instead of asking for company name again).

Related articles:

  • Can I create a multi step form?

Follow the steps below to provide a link to a PDF or other piece of content immediately after your contact fills out a form.

First, get the file URL:

Next, set the redirect URL on the landing page:

  • Navigate to Content > Landing Pages.
  • Locate and hover over your landing page until you see the Actions buttons > click Edit.
  • Locate your form and click on the form itself to edit the module.
  • From the form options window, select Redirect to another page under What should a visitor see after submitting your form?
  • Click Redirect to external URL > Paste in the URL you copied from the File Manager > click OK and you'll see your URL now in the text box.
  • Update or Publish the page.

Please keep in mind that visits to the document download will not be tracked as page views. If you prefer to track page views after form submissions, create a thank you page and link to your document from the page.

• The CAN-SPAM Act of 2003 covers commercial email messages in the United States. The European Union has a similar ePrivacy Directive.
  • The CAN-SPAM Act requires providing a visible and operable unsubscribe mechanism in all emails, and a legitimate physical address (or P.O. Box) of the business promoting its product or service.
  • HubSpot email templates are designed to include all required components of the CAN-SPAM laws, and cannot be modified to remove them. For more information, please see How to set up your email footer information
  • You can customize the text of the footer by editing the CAN-SPAM module for a particular email template.
  • To do this, go to Content > Email > Template Builder and select an email template to edit.
  • Next to the CAN-SPAM module, click on the Gear icon > Edit Options
  • For custom coded email templates, please see HubSpot Template Documentation for Email

You may create a list of contacts based on those who clicked a link in an email either by creating a smart (or static) list in the Lists tool or by creating a static list from the email statistics page. It is most efficient to create a smart list as described below because smart lists will dynamically pull in contacts as they click on links in the email, and you don't need to create a new static list each time you want the most up-to-date statistics like you would need to if you created the list from the email statistics page.

To create a smart list in the Lists tool of contacts who clicked in a specific email:

  • Navigate to Contacts > Lists > Click New List
  • Begin segmenting the following criteria:
    • Email | Contact clicked a link in email | [Name of sent email] (Note: you can only filter by emails that have already been sent -- you cannot filter by draft emails)
    • You may specify a specific link by selecting the 'and clicked on' dropdown below.
  • When ready, click Create list > Name your list > click Save

To create a static list from the email statistics of contacts who clicked any link or a specific link in a specific email:

  • Navigate to Content > Email
  • Click on Sent in the left-pane, then select the sent email in question
  • Click the Recipients tab > select Clicked
  • In the Filter by a link dropdown, select the link you'd like to filter for, or if you wish to see contacts who clicked on any/all links you do not select a specific link
  • Click on List Actions > select Create new list.
  • Name your list > click Create list - Doing so will generate a static list of contacts who clicked the link(s) in this email (which you can find under under Contacts > Lists).

When creating a list from the email statistics page, that list is a static list, and will only pull in contacts who have clicked in that email at the time the list is created. It will not update dynamically as it would if you create a smart list as described above.

Related Articles:

  • How do I create a list of contacts to which a specific email was delivered?
  • How do I create a list of contacts who opened a specific email?

If you notice multiple leads combined into a single contact record, HubSpot may be deduplicating your contacts. See this article for more information about how HubSpot deduplicates contacts.

This article explains the relationship between these elements of a contact record: the Lifecycle Stage and Close Date properties, and the Close As Customer option.

  • Two things will happen when you click the Close as Customer button on a contact record (for the first time):
    • The contact's Lifecycle Stage will be set to Customer.
    • Close Date will be set to the date the Close as Customer option was clicked.
  • If you then manually select a different Lifecycle Stage after clicking Close As Customer, (i.e. change Lifecycle Stage back to Lead), the Close Date will remain unless you manually delete the date value.
  • If you then make the contact a Customer once again, the Close Date will remain blank unless you manually input a date.
  • All future changes must be made manually after editing/removing the Close Date property value.
  • The Lifecycle Stage property and the Close As Customer option will continue to update each other accordingly even after manual changes are made.

Related articles:

  • How do I close an individual contact as a customer?
  • How to use lifecycle stages

Before a contact property's option is updated, you can select whether such should also update contacts to reflect option changes. In other words, whether you would you like X contact(s) with value 'A' to have value 'B' when the value of a contact property is updated.

  • Navigate to Contacts > Contacts Settings > Contact Properties to access the setting displayed above within a particular Contact Property.
  • Search and select the contact property in question > click on Edit Options.
  • Select the checkbox Update contacts to reflect option changes.

Related articles:

  • How can I change a contact property using Workflows?

When you're importing contacts into HubSpot, a particular contact (w/ the same email address) may be listed on the .csv file more than once. Have you ever wondered what the final result would be after such contact is imported?

  • After reviewing the .csv file, our importing functionality will only grab the first instant of the contact and deduplicate the other instances. It will not import the information associated to the other instances.
  • Furthermore, after the import is complete, you can review the corresponding error pertaining to the topic at hand.
    • Navigate to Contacts > All Contacts, and click on the Imports link on the left sidebar.
    • On the next page, locate the file you have just imported. Click on the Error link, which is to the right of the file's name - Doing so will prompt a download of the file, more specifically the errors our import function encountered.
    • In this case, for contacts that are listed more than once on the file, you will see the message 'The email [email address] has already been processed earlier in this file.' Again, this is because HubSpot only grabs the first instance of contact being listed on the file.

Related Articles:

  • If I import a list two times will it create duplicate contacts?

HubSpot deduplicates contacts on two levels, by usertoken (this is created by the HubSpot tracking code) first, then by email address.

  • Usertoken: we first look at the contact's usertoken to see if it should be merged with an existing contact. The usertoken is the cookie that HubSpot stores in the visitor's browser when they visit your page with HubSpot tracking code on it.
    • Example: if someone fills out a form on one web browser (let's say Google Chrome) then someone else fills out a form using that same browser on the same computer, the contacts will be merged together. The second form submission will overwrite the information on the first submission because they have the same usertoken (cookie) stored in their browser. (This will happen only if the second form submission email doesn't already exist in HubSpot - if the second form submission email address DOES already exist as a contact in HubSpot, that matching record will be updated with the new values from the form. However, the analytics data from the second form submission will attach to the first form submission's contact record.)
    • Learn how to prevent deduplication of form submissions based on cookies.
  • Email address: HubSpot will look for a matching email address. If a contact exists with the same email address as the one being added, the new contact information will be added to the existing contact record.
    • Example: if you import a list of contacts that includes email addresses already associated with existing contacts in HubSpot, the imported information will merge with the existing contact record. The imported property values will overwrite existing values.

Follow the steps below to import values for a single on/off checkbox field:

  • Create a column in your csv file for the property
  • Set the value on each line to either:
    • True or Yes (will display as Yes or checked in HubSpot)
    • False or No (will display as No or not checked in HubSpot)

Related articles:

  • Why am I getting the error "Cannot Parse Property" when importing a list?
  • How do I import contacts?

Contacts can only be manually added or removed from static lists. The only way to remove contacts from smart lists is to change the smart list criteria or change information on the contact record to match the smart list criteria.

To manually add a Contact to a static list:

  • Navigate to Contacts > All Contacts.
  • Find your contact and click their name.
  • Navigate to the List Memberships section.
  • Click on the Search for static lists dropdown > select the desired static list > click on Add to list.

To remove a contact from a static list:

  • Navigate to Contacts > Lists.
  • Click on the name of the static list.
  • Select the checkbox next to the contact's name and click Remove from list. 
  • When the pop-up appears, click on the blue Remove contacts button to confirm.

Please remember: Contacts cannot be manually added or deleted from smart lists because they dynamically update based on the criteria used to build the list. You will not see the same options outlined above for smart lists.

• Navigate to Contacts > Lists.
  • Select New List.
  • Name your list and choose whethere you'd like a Smart or Static List.
  • Select Form Submission > Contact has filled out form | [your form] | on any page.
  • Click Done, and then Save.

 

If you're seeing a difference between the number of contacts in your list and the number of submissions on the forms submissions page, check out this article to learn more.

Follow the steps below to create a list of contacts who have visited a particular page on your site:

  • Navigate to Contacts > Lists.
  • Click New list.
  • Next, click Name list, Add a name and  choose between a smart or static list.
  • Next in the list criteria, select  Page View > Contact has visited exact URL (or the appropriate operator for your purposes) > enter the exact URL. 
  • Click Done
  • You can now add more criteria or click Save if you are finished.

Please note: the page you're tracking this list must have been created in HubSpot or have the HubSpot Tracking Code embedded. Without the tracking code, HubSpot will not be able to collect the necessary information to associate page views with your contacts.

Yes. Follow the steps noted below to see how you can test a contact against your lead scoring attributes.

  • Go to Contacts > Lead Scoring
  • Click on the Test Contact button > search for a contact you would like to test > click the radio button next to their name/email > click Test.
  • HubSpot will proceed to review the contact and note whether it meets any of the requirements to receive any potential points.
  • You will see which attributes the tested contact meets or does not meet indicated by the red message "does not meet these requirements" or green message, "meets these requirements".

Related Articles:

  • How to use Manual Lead Scoring to automate your lead qualification

Follow the steps below to increment contacts' HubSpot Score based on page views. Please note: only Professional & Enterprise customers can create Lead Scoring rules based on page views.

  • Navigate to Contacts > Lead Scoring
  • Click + Add a rule
  • Set the rule criteria to Page View | Contact | *choose the appropriate operator* | *www.pageurl.com*
  • Save scoring rules

Read the below to learn how each of the Page View operators works:

  • Exact URL applies to visitors who have/have not visited a specific URL
    • For example, if you want to score contacts who visited http://www.yoursite.com/home BUT NOT http://www.yoursite.com/home/about, your rule could be has visited (exact URL) | http://www.yoursite.com/home
  • Part of URL applies to visitors who have/have not visited a some variation of the URL that you enter
    • For example, if you want to score contacts who visited http://www.yoursite.com/home OR http://www.yoursite.com/home/about, your rule could be has visited (part of URL) | http://www.yoursite.com/home
  • Regex is an advanced functionality that HubSpot Support does not support, so it should only by implemented by users who are familiar with Regular Expressions. RegExr is a helpful website to learn, build, & test Regular Expressions.

Related articles:

  • How to use Custom Lead Scoring to automate your lead qualification

You can import your Salesforce leads and contacts to HubSpot en masse or by campaign. To do so:

  • Navigate in HubSpot to Contacts > All Contacts
  • Click the Import button in the top, right-hand corner
  • From the Import Status dashboard, click the blue button in the top-right corner to Import Contacts
  • Check the radio button next to Import from Salesforce, then click Next
  • Select whether you want to import leads, contacts, leads and contacts, or a specific campaign/account
  • Select Begin import

Your selected leads and/or contacts will now begin to import into HubSpot. A static list of your imported records can be found under Contacts > Lists.

Want your email marketing campaigns to be as successful as possible? Follow these email template and content best practices to promote recipient engagement.

Design

Keep your template simple

Your email campaigns should focus more on your message, not the look and feel of your email. Just like it is with your website, content will always be king.

Keep email width under 600 pixels

This ensures that users of email clients such as Outlook can view your email in their vertical preview pane. Within your HubSpot email settings you can set a body width.

Optimize for mobile

It's crucial to consider your mobile audience when utilizing email marketing. Most people are reading their email on-the-go and, keeping that in mind, HubSpot has built in responsiveness to all of its email templates.

Create templates with HubSpot template builder
Coding for consistency across various email client requires understanding the HTML and CSS nuances of each client. To skip all that, use HubSpot's built in tools to create emails and ensure that they look great across major email clients and are responsive in mobile.

Use code-friendly software

When copying and pasting external custom code into rich text modules, use a simple text editor like Notepad or Sublime Text. Copying content from Word and other WYSIWYG editors typically add extra code that will cause your email to display poorly in certain email clients. Alternatively, create your content right in HubSpot's email editor.

Design with tables

While it‰Ûªs no longer best practices to design web pages with tables, they‰Ûªre essential when designing emails. It‰Ûªs the only way to have your design render correctly across multiple email clients. Please be sure to adjust the size of your table, within the source code, to correspond with the responsiveness of your email.

Use inline CSS

Email services that are browser-based, like Gmail or Hotmail, will strip out your DOCTYPE, BODY, and HEAD tags, so use inline CSS instead.

Avoid CSS shorthand

An example of CSS shorthand: <p style=‰Ûùfont: italic 14px Verdana; color: #000‰Ûù></p>

An example of correct CSS: <p style=‰Ûùfont-style: italic; font-size: 14px; font-family: Verdana; color: #000000‰Ûù></p>

Avoid external or internal CSS classes or IDs

Anything that starts with <style> will have mixed results across email clients. Instead, use inline CSS.

Avoid Javascript or other dynamic scripts

Even if a SPAM filter allows your email through, most email clients will not allow these scripts to function.

Use plain text-style bullet points

In addition to images, another element that tends to break in HTML email renderings are HTML-style bullets. To avoid the recipient seeing invisible or wonky bullets, use a plain text alternative such as asterisks (*) or dashes (‰ÛÓ) that are more likely to show up no matter what. 

Avoid Flash or video embeds

The ability to view rich media in email is turned off by default in most email clients. Instead, include an image of your video player (with a play button) that links to the rich media on a website page.

Avoid using invisible text

This is a common trick that spammers use, so it's now an instant red flag for SPAM filters.

Content

Abide by CAN-SPAM rules

You must include an unsubscribe option in every email, as well as your company name and address. In HubSpot, you cannot save an email template unless it includes this element. For your convenience, please find below helpful documentation on how to set your CAN-SPAM information within HubSpot.

  • How can I change my company address in my email footer?
  • Can I customize my CAN-SPAM email footer?
In addition to the unsubscribe link, include a link to update subscriber preferences. This way, recipients can unsubscribe from just one type of email instead of all of them! HubSpot offers subscription preferences.

Write a captivating subject line

The majority of people say they open emails based on the subject line . Keep yours to 50 characters or less for maximum impact. 

Use clear Calls to Action (CTA)

Just as you want to include CTAs on your website that link to your landing pages, you should do the same in your emails. Make your primary CTA stand out, and make it very clear what the benefit is of clicking through. Once email recipients reconvert on your site, you'll know that they're more qualified leads.

It's also good to display your CTAs early. Display your CTA near the top of your content so recipients can see it without scrolling.

Personalize your content

Using personalization tokens allows you to give the recipients of your email a more custom experience. Personalized emails also improve your click-through and conversion rates! To learn more about personalization tokens in HubSpot, check out this article. 

Use absolute paths instead of attachments

If there's something you would like to send your recipients, such as a PDF or a Word doc, don't attach the file to the email. To minimize the chance of being blocked by spam filters, and to decrease the load time of your email, instead upload the attachment to your website and link to the file location in your email using an effective Call to Action. HubSpot's attachment tool in the email editor automatically does this for you; simply highlight a bit of text or an image, and click the attachment icon. HubSpot will then turn that text or image into a link leading to that attachment.

Include "Follow Me" section

Add follow buttons or links for Facebook, Twitter, LinkedIn, or any other social media channel you actively participate in. To learn more about adding a Follow Me module to a "drag and drop" template, check out this article.

Allow recipients to share with their network

HubSpot's email tool allows you to add social sharing options in each of your emails. Take advantage of this feature to help your content go viral.

Images

Avoid background images

Outlook will not recognize background images. Instead, use a background color, and use images in other ways in your email.

Use absolute image paths

If you upload an image to an individual email using the HubSpot image library, this automatically happens for you. If including an image in an email template, host the image on your website. You could upload the image to your HubSpot file manager. Then make your image paths point to the full URL, such as: http://www.yoursite.com/yourimage.jpg.

Correct image HTML: <img src="http://www.yoursite.com/images/yourimage.jpg">

Incorrect image HTML: <img src="/images/yourimage.jpg">

Declare image width and height

This will ensure that your email design will maintain its structure when images are turned off by email clients.

Optimize image size

Make your image file sizes as small as possible without losing their visual integrity. This will prevent long email load times.

Avoid using PNG images

Lotus Notes does not support PNG image formats. Use a format such as JPG or GIF instead.

Avoid using image maps

Hotmail will not recognize image maps.

Have an even balance of text and images

Using one large image as your entire email, or too many images in general, tends to end up in recipients' SPAM folders.

Settings

Send from a real person

Avoid impersonal "info@company.com" email addresses where possible and instead send your email from an individual. Emails from generic email addresses are often ignored. 

Use preview text

Include a brief description at the very top of each email. This text will appear next to the Subject line in the inbox of some email clients and can be generated in the Preview Text section of your HubSpot email.

Always have a plain-text version of your email

Some browsers, email clients, and mobile devices can't handle HTML. While many email clients allow you to make HTML email the default setting, some also enable users to only view emails in plain text. Not solving for this type of email subscriber puts marketers at risk of alienating a portion of their subscriber base. Additionally, an HTML email without a plain-text email counterpart is a red-flag for SPAM filters. HubSpot makes it easy to pull in the text from the HTML version of your email into a plain-text version.

  • Keep the copy the same as your HTML version
    • Having no plain text version of your HTML email is a signal to SPAM filters that your email is SPAM. But the same holds true for plain text emails with copy that is much different than its HTML version. Avoid using your plain text copy to simply direct recipients to the web-based version of your email or visit a certain page on your website.
  • Use all-caps in headers
    • Because formatting elements such as bolded text, italics, headers, etc. that you'd use to emphasize important text in your HTML emails won't display in plain text versions, consider using techniques such as all caps for things like headers to help you highlight important parts of your email or to separate sections from one another.
  • Use bullet points
    • Another way to separate blocks of text or highlight important points is by using bullet points. Just as with HTML emails, this can be accomplished with asterisks (*) or dashes (‰ÛÓ).

Allow recipients to view email in web browser

Always provide this option. Even after every step is taken to assure proper email design, an email client can still display an email poorly. Include a link in every email to view the email as a web page. HubSpot makes this easy for you.

The web page version link would look like this:

Test multiple email clients

Use our Preview in other inboxes feature to send a test email and see how the design of your email looks in each email client.

Email Optimizer
Our Email Optimizer tool provides further feedback to ensure important aspects of the email message are reviewed and resolved before the actual message is sent out.

In some occasions, you may find yourself wishing to send out a test version of your email before you send out the actual email to your contacts. With HubSpot you can do just that by clicking on the Send test email icon, located towards the left side of the editor, and entering the email address that you want to send the test email to.

  • Navigate to Content > Email.
  • Select an email to test and click on the Gear icon > Edit.
  • Go towards the left side of the editor, and click on the Send test email icon.
Please note: all test emails will be from noreply@hubspot.com. This is to protect email deliverability rates. When you send the email to your contacts, it will have whatever you set as the From name and From email address. Read more about this here.

  • How do I preview email personalization?
  • Why am I not receiving test emails?
  • Can I preview my email across different clients?

In order to minimize the chance of being blocked by spam filters, and to decrease the load time of your email, HubSpot does not allow you to directly attach a file to an email. Instead, you will want to upload the file, and link it from within your email. You can do this directly within the email editor with the Insert Document Link icon.

Follow these steps to include an attached document in an email:

  • Navigate to Content > Email.
  • Choose the email you would like to add the document to.
  • Select the text or image that you would like to link.
  • Click on the Insert Document Link icon.
  • Select an existing file or click Upload a new file.
  • If you're uploading a new file, locate the document on your computer.
  • Once the file has uploaded, click Use Document.

Your linked text will now load the document for your email recipient. You can also use a CTA to link directly to the document as well.

Yes, Enterprise level customers can create different sets of addresses, enabling them to apply different Email Footer address information on an email by email basis. If you're an Enterprise level customer, please follow the directions noted below to create such sets.

  • Navigate to Content > Content Settings.
  • Select Email > Footer Information in the left hand navigation to access your CAN-SPAM configuration.
  • Click New Set to create a whole new CAN-SPAM footer that you can add to the bottom of your emails.
  • Click Save Changes.
  • The new set will be available for selection when you edit your email and click into your Email Footer section. 

If you're a Basic or Professional level customer, please note that a single office location can be entered in your CAN-SPAM settings under Content > Content Settings > Email > Footer Information. This address is the default and will be included in all of your email templates. Other addresses can be added manually per email template by following the instructions below.

  • Navigate to Content > Design Manager. Locate the email template in question and access it for editing.
  • Once inside the template, find the Office Location Information module.
  • Click on the Gear Icon > Edit Options, include any additional addresses here. The required tokens must still be included.
